etymologies: Middle English (as a noun): from Old Norse skabb; related to dialect shab (compare with shabby). The sense ‘contemptible person’ (dating from the late 16th century) was probably influenced by Middle Dutch schabbe ‘promiscuous woman’

definitions: a dry, rough protective crust that forms over a cut or wound during healing.
shortDefinitions: dry, rough protective crust that forms over cut or wound during healing

definitions: mange or a similar skin disease in animals.
shortDefinitions: mange or similar skin disease in animals

definitions: any of a number of fungal diseases of plants in which rough patches develop, especially on apples and potatoes.
shortDefinitions: several fungal diseases of plants in which rough patches develop

definitions: a person or thing regarded with dislike and disgust.
shortDefinitions: person or thing regarded with contempt

definitions: a person who refuses to strike or to join a labor union or who takes over the job responsibilities of a striking worker.
shortDefinitions: person who refuses to strike or join trade union or who takes place of striking worker

definitions: become encrusted or covered with a scab or scabs

examples.text: I had a cut on my arm that had scabbed over
the wound had barely begun to scab, let alone heal

shortDefinitions: become encrusted or covered with scab or scabs

definitions: act or work as a scab

examples.text: two inspectors who scabbed on the last strike were out this week
